The Newgate experiment was a bit more ethical, at least by 18th century standards, than it might appear. The six prisoners were all volunteers, offered pardons for participating, and, in fact, were pardoned before they were vaccinated.

One condition was that they could not have had smallpox previously. One prisoner, Richard Evans, had lied to escape execution—he had had smallpox within the past year—and Charles Maitland, the physician who carried out the experiment, noted that Evans alone among those inoculated suffered no effects from the inoculation—his actual bout of smallpox had made him immune to the effects of the inoculation. (Although he could have been hanged for lying, Evans was forgiven.)

In order to test whether the inoculation really did confer immunity on the inoculees, another inoculee, Elizabeth Harrison, was intentionally exposed to people with smallpox for ten weeks, including being ordered to sleep in the same bed with a young boy who came down with a severe form of the illness. When she did not contract the illness, Maitland accepted that the inoculation did confer immunity.

Firstly, I wouldn't say that variolation was an early form of vaccination. Rather, they are two different methods of inoculation.

Secondly, while variolation was a precursor to vaccination, as a form of inoculation, let's not pretend that the two are all that comparable, or that it was a natural progression from one to the other. A person subject to variolation could die from the procedure, and they could also cause a smallpox epidemic, even if it did inoculate them from the virus. So while there may be similarities between the two, I would caution against suggesting that vaccination was necessarily built on the work of variolation.

When it comes to the history of science, I think sometimes we need go be careful in trying to give credit to earlier developments, because it can exaggerate the role and influence of those earlier developments. It can also give the false impression that later scientists must have been influenced by those earlier works. But just as evolution can produce the same structure multiple times independently of one another, so can multiple scientists come up with similar ideas independently of one another.
